description: Wales will be without Neil Taylor for two matches after the defender was handed a suspension for his sending off during the goalless draw against the Republic of Ireland last month.
title: Wales defender Neil Taylor handed two-game suspension
title_page: Wales defender Neil Taylor handed two-game suspension | Daily Mail Online
text:
Wales will be without Neil Taylor for two crucial World Cup Qualifiers after the defender was handed a suspension for his sending off against Republic of Ireland last month.
Taylor was dismissed for a reckless lunge on Ireland captain Seamus Coleman which fractured the full-back's leg in two places.
The defender was handed an automatic one-match ban for the red card, with a second game added on as extra.
Neil Taylor reacts after being sent off for a wild lunge on Republic of Ireland's Seamus Coleman
Coleman writhes in pain as Taylor walks off the pitch having been dismissed for the tackle
Aston Villa's Taylor will now miss Wales' next two qualifiers - away at Serbia on June 11 and at home to Austria in September.
The challenge left Coleman requiring surgery on his fibula and tibula and the Everton star remains sidelined indefinitely.
Everton manager Ronald Koeman and captain Phil Jagielka visited the Ireland star in hospital to offer their support.
Coleman was photographed on Wednesday working on his injury rehabilitation at the Toffee's Finch Farm training ground.
Chris Coleman talks with Republic of Ireland manager Martin O'Neil after the goalless draw
Wales manager Chris Coleman revealed that Taylor was devastated and unable to speak in the dressing room after the foul.
The game finished in a goalless draw which left Ireland second in Group D level on points with leaders Serbia and four ahead of Wales in third.
The top teams from the nine European qualifying groups go through and the eight best runners-up make the play-offs with four of them going on to Russia 2018.
Taylor will return for the trips to Moldova and Georgia before a potential qualifying decider at home to Ireland in Wales's final match.
